ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Effect of the period of cultivation on concentrations of total P at a depth of 0–10cm in five soils. Where significant relationships were found, the soils were plotted on the left (a) and the coefficients presented in Table 1.

Effect of the period of cultivation on concentrations of organic P (a, b), total inorganic P (c, d), and bicarbonate-extractable P (e, f) at a depth of 0–10cm in five soils. Where significant relationships were found, the soils were plotted on the left (a, c, e) and the coefficients presented in Table 1.
Effect of the period of cultivation on concentrations of organic P in the Waco soil at depths ranging from 0 to 0.1m to 0.9–1.2m.

Effect of the duration of cultivation on the (a) C/P ratios and (b) organic C concentrations of five soils. (c,d) The relationship between organic P and organic C concentrations, with significant relationships shown in (c).

(a) Yield and (b) grain tissue P concentration as influenced by the period of cultivation. The relationship between grain tissue P concentration and concentration of (c) soil organic P and (d) soil inorganic P. Linear regressions were fitted where significant relationships were found.

Initial values (Po), equilibrium values (Pe), overall rate of loss (kc) and half-life of loss (t1/2) of P from the top layer (0–0.1m) of five soils. Where a significant relationship was found using linear regression, values are presented for the average annual decrease in P (a).

Yield and removal of P in wheat grain as related to decreases in soil total P and soil organic P (assuming removal from 0 to 10cm only). Where significant effects were found (NS, not significant), values presented are the average annual decrease calculated from the regressions (Table 1), using the bulk density values (Supplementary Table S1). For organic P in Cecilvale, Riverview, and Thallon, the relationship was linear (Fig. 2a) and hence the predicted decrease in organic P did not change over time. The decreases in total and organic P were calculated using the bulk densities shown in Supplementary Table S1.

row.entry: Decrease in soil total P (kgha −1 y−1)
Decrease in soil organic P (kg ha −1 y−1)

head.ce:title: Effects of long-term cultivation on phosphorus (P) in five low-input, subtropical Australian soils

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Centre for Soil and Environmental Sciences
School of Agriculture and Food Sciences

ce:list-item.ce:para: We examined the impact of agricultural cropping for up to 70y on soil P.
Inorganic P remained constant but organic P decreased by up to 36%.
The C/P ratio remained constant despite the decrease in organic P.
The rate of P removal exceeded fertilizer inputs.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Despite the importance of P for cropping, there remains uncertainty regarding the effects of long-term cropping on P behaviour in soils. Using five soils (Billa Billa, Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco) from subtropical Australia cropped for ≤70y with low rates of P-fertilizer inputs, changes in soil P (organic, inorganic, and total) were assessed and related to P removal in wheat grain. For four of the five soils, concentrations of organic P decreased significantly with increasing period of cropping, decreasing between 20 and 36%. In contrast, concentrations of inorganic P generally remained relatively constant. Despite the decrease in organic P, the C/P ratio remained relatively constant in all five soils (average of 99), indicating that organic P is protected within the soil organic matter in a manner similar to the organic C. Furthermore, although increasing period of cropping decreased soil organic P concentrations, grain P concentrations decreased significantly only for Billa Billa and Thallon. Finally, although the rate of P removal in grain was low (1.6 to 9.3kg ha −1 y−1), the rate of removal exceeded inputs from P-containing fertilizers. Thus, there is a need to consider the long-term P-fertilization to ensure adequate P nutrition of the crops. This study provides important information regarding changes in P within long-term cropping systems and will assist in their sustainable management.

ce:section.ce:para: An estimated two-thirds of soils worldwide contain insufficient P for optimal plant growth (Batjes, 1997; Cakmak, 2002). Furthermore, in Australia (and many other tropical and subtropical regions), issues of P deficiency are even more pronounced due to the high degree of weathering in ancient soils (Walker and Syers, 1976). As a result of the inherently low concentrations of P, the addition of P as fertilizers is essential to maintain and increase agricultural production. Currently, an estimated 261 million tons of phosphate rock are used annually for crop production (U.S. Geological Survey, 2017). Furthermore, it is estimated that demand for P will increase by 50–100% by the year 2050 due to increasing demand for food production and shifts in diet compositions (Steen, 1998; EFMA, 2000). Of the 14 nutrients that are essential for plants, global reserves of P are the smallest (Gilbert, 2009) with the majority of these in a single country, Morocco. As a result, the use of the remaining P reserves must be efficient, with supply of P fertilizers influenced both by scarcity and political instability.

To achieve this increased efficiency, a better understanding of how agricultural cropping practices influence the behaviour of soil P is needed, particularly in low-input systems. Low-input agricultural systems are defined here as those with low external inputs, particularly fertilizers. For example, yields in many cropping systems of Australia are often limited by a water deficit, with external inputs (including fertilizer) also low as a result. Despite the importance of P and its fertilization for global food production, there remains a lack of a detailed understanding about how P changes in soils over time as a result of cropping practices in long-term agricultural systems (Kopittke et al., 2017). This lack of understanding hinders ongoing research efforts to improve the efficiency of P usage and to increase crop productivity in P-limited soils. Of particular interest to the present study, despite the inherently low P concentrations of many soils, several studies have shown that long-term cultivation and product removal have resulted in further substantial reductions in soil P concentrations (Hedley et al., 1982; Tiessen et al., 1983; Beck and Sanchez, 1994; Dalal, 1997; Motavalli and Miles, 2002; Kopittke et al., 2017). Generally, these previous studies have found that long-term cropping results in appreciable decreases in organic P concentrations, whilst inorganic P often (but not always) remains relatively constant. For example, Bowman et al. (1990) found that after cropping for 60y, organic P concentrations decreased by 47% whilst inorganic P concentrations decreased by only 11%. In the present study, we extend these previous findings by examining long-term changes in five low-input subtropical cropping systems of Australia.

Primary soil minerals, mainly apatites, are the original source of 95% or more of the P in soils, with this P released during mineral dissolution ( Stevenson, 1999). As a result, few of these primary minerals are found in highly weathered soils. Rather, the majority of P in weathered soils is associated either with secondary soil minerals or with soil organic matter – these two pools accounting for 98–99% in weathered soils. The relative importance of these two pools (i.e. organic P and inorganic P associated with secondary minerals) varies depending upon soil properties and mineralogy, with between 20 and 80% present as organic P and 20–80% present as inorganic P in secondary minerals (Stevenson, 1999). The relative importance of changes in these organic and inorganic fractions upon long-term cultivation remains unclear, with few studies examining these changes in low-input systems, particularly in tropical and subtropical soils ( Hedley et al., 1982; Tiessen et al., 1983; Dalal, 1997; Motavalli and Miles, 2002; Crews and Brookes, 2014). In an interesting study, MacDonald et al. (2012) utilized a meta-analysis and reported that abandonment of agricultural land generally resulted in increases in soil P concentrations.

The present study aimed to examine the effects of long-term (≤70y) cultivation and product removal on concentrations of P in soil and wheat grain from five systems in sub-tropical Australia. These five soils received either no P fertilizer or it was applied at low rates. Examining the surface 0–10cm of the soil profile, changes in total P, organic P, inorganic P, and plant-available P (estimated using bicarbonate-extractable P) were assessed. These changes in organic P were also related to those of organic C. Finally, consideration was given to the concentration of P in wheat grain and the magnitude with which it is exported from the agricultural systems. This information is important in understanding the impacts of long-term cropping systems on soil nutrient reserves and will assist in the sustainable management of these soils.

Soils were collected from five locations in southern Queensland (Australia), with the locations being called Billa Billa, Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco. Mean annual rainfall ranges from 480mm for Thallon to 670mm for Cecilvale. A detailed history of all five sites is provided by Dalal and Mayer (1986a), but is briefly summarized here. Of the winter crops grown at these five sites, 90% were wheat (Triticum aestivum see later), with 90% of summer crops being sorghum (Sorghum bicolor). The average number of winter crops and summer crops each year was 0.8 (winter) and 0.1 (summer) at Billa Billa, 0.6 and 0.2 at Cecilvale, 0.5 and 0.2 at Riverview, 0.6 and 0.1 at Thallon, and 0.6 and 0.3 at Waco. At all five sites, applications of P-containing fertilizers were low, ranging from 0 to 7.7 kgha −1 y −1 (Supplementary Table S1). The P-fertilizers were typically applied as monoammonium phosphate. Soils were generally cultivated using a chisel plough, sweep plough and scarifier, or occasionally a disc plough. The average number of cultivation operations per year was 4.8 for Billa Billa, 4.9 for Cecilvale, 2.9 for Riverview, 3.0 for Thallon, and 5.0 for Waco.

For each location, samples were collected from various nearby fields that differed in the length of time since being first cultivated. Thus, these samples represented soils that had been cropped for ≤70y, with samples collected from a total of 64 individual cropped sites across the five locations (being 14 sites for Billa Billa, 12 for Cecilvale, 11 for Riverview, 14 for Thallon, and 13 for Waco). Samples were also collected from nearby undisturbed (virgin) sites with native vegetation, with up to seven sites used for the undisturbed samples at each of the five locations. (Multiple sites were used for the undisturbed samples to ensure that all samples collected from cultivated sites had an adjacent undisturbed site for comparison). Unless otherwise stated, all data presented hereafter for the undisturbed sites (0y cultivation) is the average across the ≤7 sites at each location. In total, 94 individual sites were sampled, being 64 cropped sites and 30 undisturbed sites.

At each individual site, samples were collected across a 0.1ha area using a 5 ×8m grid at a depth of 0 to 0.1 m. A total of 25 samples were collected from each of the 94 sites (i.e. 2350 samples in total), with five of these samples then mixed to form a single composite sample (yielding a total of five composite samples for each of the 94 sites). Upon collection, the soil samples were placed in plastic bags and stored at 4 °C until further processing. Thereafter, the soil samples were dried at 25 °C in an oven, ground to pass a 2mm sieve, and stored in sealed plastic containers at room temperature until analysis. Samples of wheat straw and grain were collected where possible.

The soils have been described in detail previously (Dalal and Mayer, 1986a; Kopittke et al., 2016), with some properties presented here (Supplementary Table S1). All soils were Vertisols (Vertisols in the World Reference Base classification system) other than Riverview which was an Alfisol (Lixisol in the World Reference Base classification system). The parent material at Billa Billa is calcareous sediments, at Cecilvale it is clay alluvium derived from basalt and sandstone, at Riverview it is weathered ferruginized sediments, at Thallon it is Quaternary argillaceous alluvium, and at Waco it is clay alluvium derived from basalt. For undisturbed soils, pH values were near-neutral or alkaline, organic C contents were modest (0.78–1.7%), with clay content highest for Waco (72%) and lowest for Riverview (18%).

Estimates of available P concentrations were made using sodium bicarbonate (Colwell, 1963; Rayment and Lyons, 2011). Organic P was determined as described by Saunders and Williams (1955), total P concentrations were determined using X-ray fluorescence (Rayment and Lyons, 2011), and inorganic P was determined as the difference between total and organic P. The organic C concentration was determined using the Walkley-Black method. After drying at 65 °C for 48h, plant tissues were digested in concentrated HNO3 before analysis. The concentrations of P in the soil extracts and the plant digests were assessed colorimetrically using the ascorbic acid method (Murphy and Riley, 1962).

Data were analysed using SYSTAT 13.1 (Cranes Software, India), with changes in P concentrations assessed using the first-order kinetic model, similar to that for N (Stanford and Smith, 1972),
(1) P t =Pe + (P 0–Pe)exp(-kt)
where P t
is the concentration of P after t years, P e
is the concentration of P at equilibrium following a long period of cultivation, P 0
is the P concentration prior to disturbance (virgin site), and k is the rate of P loss per year. For Eq. (1), the half-life ( t ½
) can be calculated as: ln2/k. Where 95% confidence intervals encompassed zero, changes in P were instead examined using linear regressions
(2) P t =P 0–at
where a is the average annual decrease in P. Throughout this study, no coefficient is reported (and regressions are not plotted) where the 95% confidence interval encompassed zero.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Changes in soil P concentrations in the topsoil (0–0.1m depth)
ce:section.ce:para: Of the five soils (Supplementary Table S2), the soil total P concentration decreased significantly over time for only Thallon, with the predicted total P concentration decreasing by 42% from 484mgkg −1 in the undisturbed soil to 282mgkg −1 after cultivation for 23y ( Fig. 1 a). The predicted equilibrium value for Thallon was 249mgkg −1 ( Table 1 ), representing an overall decrease of 49%. Particularly for Waco, it was noted that the total P concentration was highly variable, ranging from 210 to 990 mgkg −1 (Fig. 1b). For the remaining four soils, Billa Billa, Cecilvale, Riverview, or Waco, overall variability was considerably lower, but no significant relationship was found between period of cultivation and total P concentration (Fig. 1b).

Next, changes in the various individual P pools were examined, being organic P, inorganic P, and bicarbonate-extractable P. Overall, for the undisturbed soils, the majority of soil-P was inorganic, accounting for ca. 56% of the total P in Billa Billa, 51% in Cecilvale, 72% in Riverview, 72% in Thallon, and 79% in Waco (Supplementary Table S1). Interestingly, although changes in total P were not significant for Cecilvale, Riverview, or Waco (Fig. 1b), cultivation resulted in significant decreases in organic P for these three soils plus Thallon ( Fig. 2 a). The overall magnitude of this decrease was greatest for Waco (from 144 to 92mgkg −1 after 70y cultivation, being a 36% decrease), compared to Cecilvale (from 143 to 98mgkg −1 after 35y cultivation, being a 31% decrease), Thallon (from 114 to 89mgkg −1 after 23y cultivation, being a 22% decrease), and Riverview (from 89 to 71 mgkg −1 after 20y cultivation, being a 20% decrease) ( Fig. 2a and Table 1). In contrast to these observations for organic P, cultivation caused concentrations of inorganic P to decrease significantly in Thallon (45% after 23y, from 318 to 175mgkg−1, Fig. 2c), but not in Billa Billa, Cecilvale, Riverview, or Waco (Fig. 2d). In a similar manner, bicarbonate-extractable P concentrations decreased significantly in Thallon (78% after 23y, from 32 to 7.1mgkg −1, Fig. 2e) but not in the other four soils (Fig. 2f).

Given that, at a depth of 0–0.1m, changes were most pronounced for organic P (Fig. 2), we examined whether any changes were also evident when also including deeper layers in the analyses (0–0.2m, 0–0.3m, and so forth). However, for these deeper soil layers, no significant relationships were found between period of cultivation and organic P concentration for any soil (data are presented in Fig. 3
for Waco, which is the soil that had the largest changes in organic P at a depth of 0–0.1 m, Fig. 2a).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Relationships between organic P and organic C
ce:section.ce:para: The C/P ratio remained relatively constant (average of 99) irrespective of the period of cultivation, with no significant trends found for any of the five soils ( Fig. 4 a). For Waco, for example, the constant C/P ratio occurred because as organic P concentrations decreased over time (Fig. 2a) there was a concomitant decrease in organic C concentrations (Fig. 4b). For the other soils, the decreases in organic P tended to be more modest (Fig. 2a and b), with organic C concentrations also tended to decrease more modestly (Fig. 4b).

For Cecilvale and Waco, a significant linear relationship was found between organic P and organic C, whilst no relationships were found for Billa Billa, Riverview, or Thallon (Fig. 4c and d). For Waco, the linear regression had a slope of 87.9, representing a decrease in organic P of 87.9mgkg −1 for every 1% decrease in organic C (Fig. 4c), that is, C/P ratio of 114. Similarly, the slope of the linear regression for Cecilvale was 107, corresponding to a decrease in organic P of 107mg kg −1 for every 1% decrease in organic C (Fig. 4c), with a C/P ratio of 93.

Wheat yield varied substantially depending upon soil type, being highest in Waco (average of 2.4tha−1) and lowest in Riverview (average of 0.55tha −1) ( Fig. 5 a). Although there was a general trend for yield to decrease slightly with increasing period of cultivation, this trend was not significant for any soil except Waco (Fig. 5a). Grain P concentrations were not influenced by the period of cultivation for Cecilvale, Riverview, or Waco, with grain P concentrations remaining relatively constant irrespective of how long the soil had been cultivated for (Fig. 5b). However, for Billa Billa and Thallon, grain P concentrations were found to decrease significantly over time, decreasing from 0.41 to 0.30% after cultivation for 23y (Fig. 5b). Interestingly, for Thallon, this decrease in grain P concentrations was related to the decrease in soil concentrations of organic P (Fig. 5c) but was not related to changes in soil inorganic P (Fig. 5d) or to bicarbonate-extractable P (data not presented).

Based upon their yield and grain P concentrations, the amount of P removed annually in the wheat grain ranged from 1.6kgha −1 (Riverview) to 9.3kgha −1 (Waco) ( Table 2 ). Given that it was only for Thallon that the total concentration of P in the soil decreased upon increasing cultivation ( Fig. 1a), the average annual decrease in total soil P was calculated only for this soil as being 8.4kgha −1 (Table 2). However, the rate of decrease in total soil P was not constant but decreased over time, ranging from 18kgha −1 upon initial cultivation to 2.8kgha −1 after cultivation for 23y (Table 2 and Fig. 1a). Finally, we calculated the average annual decrease in organic P for Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco, which ranged from 0.64 to 1.3kgha −1 y −1 (Table 2).

The effects of cultivation and product removal on soil P concentrations were examined for five soils, Billa Billa, Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco. Although concentrations of inorganic P were higher than those of organic P (inorganic P accounting for 51 to 79% of total P), it was the organic P fraction that tended to decrease with cultivation (Fig. 2). For four of the five soils, concentrations of organic P decreased significantly with cultivation. Indeed, comparing only the undisturbed soils and those soils with the greatest period of cultivation, the predicted decrease in organic P was 31% for Cecilvale, 20% for Riverview, 22% for Thallon, and 36% for Waco (Fig. 2a). Thus, for the soils examined in the present study, organic P appears to be more sensitive to long-term cultivation and cropping practices (Fig. 2a–d).

These results are similar to those reported in other studies examining organic and inorganic P in long-term cropping systems, although the magnitude of the reduction in the present study is somewhat smaller than previously reported. For example, Motavalli and Miles (2002) examined soils of the Great Plains of North America, and found that whilst inorganic P remained constant after cultivation for 111y, concentrations of organic P decreased by ca. 75% in unfertilized soils. Similarly, Hedley et al. (1982) found that 74% of the decrease in total P was due to loss of organic P, while Dalal (1997) found a decrease in both inorganic P (40%) and organic P (41%). Similar results have also been reported by Beck and Sanchez (1994) and Solomon et al. (2002). This decrease in organic P is also consistent with the comparatively well-studied decrease in organic C, organic N, and organic S reported for long-term cropping systems ( Bettany et al., 1980; Dalal and Mayer, 1986c; Murty et al., 2002; Bhupinderpal et al., 2004; Malo et al., 2005; Don et al., 2011; Kopittke et al., 2016, 2017). For example, in a meta-analysis, Kopittke et al. (2017) reported that long-term conversion of native vegetation to cropping land results in an average 42% decrease in both C and N.

In the present study, the predicted decrease in organic P for the four soils ranged from 20% for the Alfisol (Riverview) and from 22% (Thallon) to 36% (Waco) for the Vertisols. Thus, despite the range in textures (clay content ranging from 18 to 72%, Kopittke et al. (2016)), there was no apparent trend in the decrease in organic P across these four soils. Indeed, the decrease in organic P in these low production (low rainfall) soils was substantially less than the median reduction in P stocks reported in the global meta-analysis of Kopittke et al. (2017). These authors identified six previous studies examining the changes in organic P stocks upon long-term conversion of virgin vegetation to traditional cropping systems, with the median decrease in organic P across these previous studies being 50%. Thus, it seems that the decrease in organic P stocks is likely related to a range of factors (for example, climatic factors), although the broad importance of soil-related factors cannot be discounted.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Changes in inorganic P and total P
ce:section.ce:para:
Overall, changes in inorganic P varied between soils, with concentrations decreasing significantly (Thallon), remaining relatively constant (Billa Billa, Cecilvale, and Riverview), or being highly variable (Waco) (Fig. 2c and d). First, we considered Billa Billa, Cecilvale, and Riverview, where concentrations of inorganic P remained relatively constant. This observation for these three soils is in general agreement with previous studies that have found that long-term cropping often does not have a substantial impact on inorganic P. For example, studying soils from the Great Plains of North America, Tiessen et al. (1982) reported that inorganic P concentrations changed by +17 to −6.2% in soils cultivated for up to 90y, which was in contrast to organic P concentrations which changed by −15 to −24%. Similarly, Bowman et al. (1990) reported that inorganic P concentrations changed by −11% after cropping for 60y (organic P concentrations changed by −63%), whilst Dalal (1997) found that both inorganic and organic P changed by ca. 40%. It is noteworthy, however, that in systems receiving appreciable inorganic P fertilizers, soil concentrations of inorganic P can increase markedly (Agbenin and Goladi, 1997). Given that total P concentrations were dominated by inorganic P (Supplementary Table S1), it is not surprising that changes in total P (Fig. 1) for Billa Billa, Cecilvale, and Riverview were similar to those described above for inorganic P ( Fig. 2c and d). Furthermore, although concentrations of organic P decreased significantly, because the contribution of organic P to the total concentration of P was comparatively small, the predicted decreases in organic P (18 to 52
mg/kg, Fig. 2a) represented only a modest change in the total P (5.5–14% of total P).

Next, closer attention was given to the inorganic P and total P concentrations for Thallon (for which inorganic and total P concentrations decreased significantly) and for Waco (for which inorganic and total P concentrations appeared to have high variability) (Figs. 1 and 2). For Thallon, the large decreases in soil P could not be explained by product removal, with the average decrease in total soil P (8.4kgha −1 y−1) being approximately double the amount being removed in the grain (4.7kgha −1 y−1, Table 2, also see later discussion). Coupled with the high variability in inorganic P for Waco, we investigated whether these changes in inorganic (and total) P concentrations could indeed be attributed to cropping, or if they were actually due to underlying variability between the various fields used to collect the samples. Given that samples had been collected from up to seven undisturbed sites at each of the five locations (with the various undisturbed sites designed to identify any potential changes across the landscape between cultivated sites), we examined variation between the undisturbed samples (Supplementary Fig. S1). Firstly, for these undisturbed sites, it was noted that variation in inorganic P was substantially greater than for organic P, particularly for Thallon and Waco. For example, at Thallon, organic P concentrations varied by 36% between sites, whilst inorganic P concentrations differed by 120% (Supplementary Fig. S1). Next, given that samples had been collected from multiple undisturbed sites at each of the five locations, we calculated relative changes in inorganic and organic P concentrations by comparing values from cropped soils with only the undisturbed closest to that particular field. [This is in contrast to the absolute concentrations presented inFigs. 1–4, where values for undisturbed (0 y cultivation) soils were calculated as the average across all undisturbed sites from that location]. This data showed that across all five locations (Billa Billa, Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco), inorganic P concentrations tended to remain constant while organic P concentrations decreased (Supplementary Fig. S2 and Supplementary Fig. S3), thereby confirming our general observations from absolute values (Figs. 1 and 2).

Based upon these observations, we hypothesise that for both Thallon and Waco, the observed changes in inorganic P upon cultivation ( Figs. 1 and 2) were actually experimental ‘artefacts’, and that these changes were not solely associated cropping per se. Specifically, we propose that particularly for Thallon and Waco, variations in the underlying soil material between fields (with fields representing different periods of cultivation) resulted in concomitant changes in soil inorganic P concentrations. For Thallon, this change appeared to be systematic and was associated with the progressive conversion of land to cropping along a gradient. The Thallon soil is a flood-plain alluvium, which has presumably been affected by variation in sediment sources, delivering parent materials of different P concentrations. Importantly, however, these observations regarding the variability in inorganic P in Thallon and Waco is in contrast to that observed for organic P in these same samples (Fig. 2) and for organic C, N, and S in these same soils (Dalal and Mayer, 1986b, 1986c; Kopittke et al., 2016). Specifically, the data suggest that for elements closely associated with organic matter (organic P, but also C, N, and organic S), the current sampling approach has provided important data, but for elements associated more closely with underlying parent material, care needs to be taken in case of associated variability. Indeed, it is known that whilst organic matter is closely related to climatic conditions (Parton et al., 1987) (which, for the present study, would have negligible variability between fields) particularly in dry environments like Australia, inorganic P concentrations depend largely upon the underlying parent material.

Finally, it should also be noted that it has been reported that the total P concentrations are highest in the most easily dispersed clay fraction (Scalenghe et al., 2007). In such studies, selective erosion would result in the loss of the soil fraction with the highest P concentrations. However, for the sites examined in the present study, erosion rates were likely to low, given the low slopes and stability of these soils (Dalal and Mayer, 1986a). Furthermore, the 12 European soils examined by Scalenghe et al. (2007) were of high fertility and were overfertilized, which contrasts with the current systems which are inherently of low fertility and also have a negative P budget (Supplementary Table S1 and Table 2).

For Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco, organic P concentrations decreased significantly over time (Fig. 2a). However, despite these decreases in organic P, the C/P ratio was ≤177 and did not change significantly over time in any of the five soils ( Fig. 4a). Indeed, for all soils, it was observed that there was a concomitant reduction in organic C concentrations (Fig. 4b). However, the relationship between organic P and organic C was significant only for Cecilvale and Waco (Fig. 4c and d), indicating that, for these two soils, organic P is protected within the soil organic matter in a manner similar to the organic C. This difference between that observed for Cecilvale and Waco and the three other soils ( Fig. 4c and d) could not be attributed to differences in the C/P ratio, with similar values in Billa Billa, Riverview, and Waco (although Thallon had somewhat lower values) (Fig. 4a). However, it was noted that Waco did indeed have the highest organic C content (Supplementary Table S1) and the largest decrease in organic C (Fig. 4b), albeit it was also cultivated for much longer period than the other soils.

This variable effect of cropping on C/P ratios is similar to that reported previously. Tiessen et al. (1982) found that for organic P after cultivation for up to 90y, C/P ratios decreased from 74 to 48. In contrast, Bowman et al. (1990) found that for the surface 0–15cm, cropping for up to 60y had no impact on C/P ratios, which were similar in both the virgin soil (C/P ratio of 97) and soil cropped for 60y (C/P ratio of 96). Similarly, for the unfertilized soil studying by Agbenin and Goladi (1997), cropping for 45y did not change the C/P ratio, with the ratio being 21 in the undisturbed soil and 23 in the cropped soil. It has recently been reported that P transformations in low-P soils can reduce both soil organic C and the C/P ratio, potentially suggesting that crops growing in low-P soils may deplete the soil organic matter from protected mineral-organic associations (Romanyà et al., 2017). However, in the present study, C/P ratios did not appear to change with long-term cropping (Fig. 4a).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Availability and concentration in wheat grain
ce:section.ce:para: For the present study, as a result of the low yields (0.55–2.4tha −1 y−1), the rate of P removal in grain (1.6–9.3 kgha −1 y−1, Table 2) was low relative to those published elsewhere (for example, see Motavalli and Miles, 2002). Regardless, it was noted that the rate of P removal in grain generally exceeded the P supplied through mineralisation of organic P (Table 2), with the balance presumably supplied from the soil’s inorganic P reserves. Furthermore, the rate of P removal in these low-input systems exceeded the rate at which P fertilizers were added (Supplementary Table S1), demonstrating the need to consider long-term P-fertilization to ensure adequate P nutrition of the crop. This is in agreement with the negative P budgets reported for much of Australia (NLWRA, 2001). Globally, however, total inputs of P to agricultural systems exceed removal in agricultural products (Bouwman et al., 2009). Regardless, care must also be taken to ensure that the application of P fertilizers does not result in eutrophication, with the erosion of P-enriched soils being of major concern (Steffen et al., 2015).

The present study has shown that in low-input systems, long-term cropping can result in decreases in soil organic P. Specifically, for Cecilvale, Riverview, Thallon, and Waco, concentrations of organic P decreased with increasing period of cultivation, with concentrations decreasing by 20–36%. Despite the range in textures across the soils examined (clay content ranging from 18 to 72%), there was no apparent trend in the decrease in organic P across the various soils. Concentrations of inorganic P generally remained relatively constant, although concentrations decreased significantly in Thallon and were highly variable in Waco. It is hypothesised that, for these two soils, measured changes in inorganic P were confounded by variations in the underlying parent material. Regardless, despite the progressive decrease in soil organic P, the C/P ratio remained relatively constant due to the concomitant loss of organic C. Concentrations of P in wheat grain were generally stable, decreasing significantly only in Billa Billa and Thallon. Finally, although the rate of P removal in grain was low (1.6–9.3kgha −1 y−1), the rate of removal exceeded inputs from P-containing fertilizers and thus there is a need to consider the long-term P-fertilization to ensure adequate P nutrition.
